elements.content: Aluminum-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [Al­(OH)­(SDC)] n , (H2SDC: 4,4′-stilbenedicarboxylic acid), also known as CYCU-3, were prepared by means of the coordination modulation method to produce materials with different crystal size and morphology. In particular, we screened several reagent concentrations (20–60 mM) and modulator/ligand ratios (0–50), leading to 20 CYCU x_y materials (x: reagent concentration, y = modulator/ligand ratio) with different particle size and morphology. Noteworthy, the use of high modulator/ligand ratio gives rise to a new phase of CYCU-3 (CYCU-3′ x_50 series), which was structurally analyzed. Afterward, to test the potential of these materials as CO-prodrug carriers, we selected three of them to adsorb the photo- and bioactive CO-releasing molecule (CORM) ALF794 [Mo­(CNCMe2CO2H)3(CO)3] (CNCMe2CO2H = 2-isocyano-2-methyl propionic acid): (i) CYCU-3 20_0, particles in the nanometric range; (ii) CYCU-3 50_5, bar-type particles with heterogeneous size, and (iii) CYCU-3′ 50_50, a new phase analogous to pristine CYCU-3. The corresponding hybrid materials were fully characterized, revealing that CYCU-3 20_0 with the smallest particle size was not stable under the drug loading conditions. Regarding the other two materials, similar ALF794 loadings were found (0.20 and 0.19 CORM/MOF molar ratios for ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50, respectively). In addition, these hybrid systems behave as CO-releasing materials (CORMAs), retaining the photoactive properties of the pristine CORM in both phosphate saline solution and solid state. Finally, the metal leaching studies in solution confirmed that ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50 shows a good retention capacity toward the potentially toxic molybdenum fragments (75% of retention after 72 h), which is the lowest value reported for a MOF-based CORMA to date.

elements.content: Since the pioneering work of Nobel laureates Furchgott, Ignarro, and Murad concerning nitric oxide (NO) as an important biosignaling molecule in the cardiovascular system, significant attention has been paid on the physiological and potential therapeutic roles of other endogenously produced small gas molecules, such as carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen sulfide (H2S). Among these gases, CO exhibits lower reactivity than NO or H2S, acting only as a ligand for metalloproteins. This different behavior has an advantage in biomedical applications as CO is most likely to reach the cellular target intact. In this context, carbon monoxide has already shown antihypertensive, anti-inflammatory, and cell-protective effects, demonstrating its potential as a therapeutic tool if supplied exogenously in low concentrations. The easiest administration route for this gas molecule into the body is by the inhalation of CO/air mixtures. Indeed, several clinical trials have been completed or are currently in progress to evaluate the safety and efficacy of inhaled CO against several diseases. However, this delivery strategy lacks specificity as CO distribution is determined by the fixed partition coefficients between the different body fluids and tissues. In addition, the higher affinity of CO to hemoglobin compared to oxygen, as well as its poor solubility in water, means that high doses of inhaled CO are required to obtain a beneficial effect with the concomitant associated safety risk.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since the pioneering work of Nobel laureates Furchgott, Ignarro, and Murad concerning nitric oxide (NO) as an important biosignaling molecule in the cardiovascular system, significant attention has been paid on the physiological and potential therapeutic roles of other endogenously produced small gas molecules, such as carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen sulfide (H2S). Among these gases, CO exhibits lower reactivity than NO or H2S, acting only as a ligand for metalloproteins. This different behavior has an advantage in biomedical applications as CO is most likely to reach the cellular target intact. In this context, carbon monoxide has already shown antihypertensive, anti-inflammatory, and cell-protective effects, demonstrating its potential as a therapeutic tool if supplied exogenously in low concentrations. The easiest administration route for this gas molecule into the body is by the inhalation of CO/air mixtures. Indeed, several clinical trials have been completed or are currently in progress to evaluate the safety and efficacy of inhaled CO against several diseases. However, this delivery strategy lacks specificity as CO distribution is determined by the fixed partition coefficients between the different body fluids and tissues. In addition, the higher affinity of CO to hemoglobin compared to oxygen, as well as its poor solubility in water, means that high doses of inhaled CO are required to obtain a beneficial effect with the concomitant associated safety risk.

elements.content: To overcome these drawbacks, Motterlini et al. introduced the concept of CO-releasing molecules (CORMs) and demonstrated, for the first time, the feasibility of using metal carbonyls to release CO inducing beneficial vascular effects. Since then, several CO-prodrugs have been designed from the readily available and highly tailorable metal and ligand precursors to control the number of CO molecules released and/or the triggering mechanism of CO delivery (e.g., light, physiological changes, and enzyme activation). Unfortunately, despite the highly versatile chemistry of these prodrugs, most of them have low solubility and/or stability in physiological media, fast CO release, and undesirable toxic effects associated to their decarbonylation products, which prevent their clinical development.
elements.clean_text: To overcome these drawbacks, Motterlini et al. introduced the concept of CO-releasing molecules (CORMs) and demonstrated, for the first time, the feasibility of using metal carbonyls to release CO inducing beneficial vascular effects. Since then, several CO-prodrugs have been designed from the readily available and highly tailorable metal and ligand precursors to control the number of CO molecules released and/or the triggering mechanism of CO delivery (e.g., light, physiological changes, and enzyme activation). Unfortunately, despite the highly versatile chemistry of these prodrugs, most of them have low solubility and/or stability in physiological media, fast CO release, and undesirable toxic effects associated to their decarbonylation products, which prevent their clinical development.

elements.content: One smart approach to overcome the abovementioned weaknesses is the combination of the existing CORMs with biocompatible solids, resulting in CO-releasing materials (CORMAs). Such hybrid systems are expected to maintain the triggering properties of the pristine CORM, improve its chemical stability in the physiological medium, and retain the potentially toxic co-ligand fragments. Besides, for biomedical applications, apart from the toxicity issues, particle size and morphology of the carrier should be taken into account, not only to assess the appropriate administration route (e.g., intravenous route requires particle diameter less than 200 nm, whereas bigger particles, even in the micrometric range, may be used for oral administration or topical applications), but also to exert a certain control on the cargo, drug delivery process, and chemical stability of the resulting hybrid material.
elements.clean_text: One smart approach to overcome the abovementioned weaknesses is the combination of the existing CORMs with biocompatible solids, resulting in CO-releasing materials (CORMAs). Such hybrid systems are expected to maintain the triggering properties of the pristine CORM, improve its chemical stability in the physiological medium, and retain the potentially toxic co-ligand fragments. Besides, for biomedical applications, apart from the toxicity issues, particle size and morphology of the carrier should be taken into account, not only to assess the appropriate administration route (e.g., intravenous route requires particle diameter less than 200 nm, whereas bigger particles, even in the micrometric range, may be used for oral administration or topical applications), but also to exert a certain control on the cargo, drug delivery process, and chemical stability of the resulting hybrid material.

elements.content: In this context, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have recently gained especial importance as promising CO carriers. However, to the best of our knowledge, only four CORMAs based on MOFs have been published to date. The first CO delivery system using a MOF as a platform was prepared by Metzler-Nolte et al. In this case, carbon monoxide was reversibly captured on the unsaturated coordination sites of MIL-88B-Fe derivatives to be delivered later by simple degradation of the matrixes. Afterward, some of the authors, Maldonado, Barea et al., prepared a photoactive CORM@MOF system by a cation exchange methodology on the biocompatible bioMOF-1. However, the scarce stability of the resulting hybrid material in a buffered solution led to the complete leaching of the CORM in a short time frame. More recently, Furukawa et al. have designed a covalently attached CORM@MOF system by embedding a photoactive manganese complex into a robust Zr­(IV)–MOF. In this case, CO delivery was monitored in the solid state. Finally, Barea, Maldonado et al. reported for the first time the one-pot synthesis of a new CORM@MOF system by incorporating the CORM [Mo­(CNCMe2CO2H)3(CO)3] (ALF794) into the textural mesopores of the hierarchical structure of [Zn2(dhtp)] (dhtp = 2,5-dihydroxyterephtalate) (h-ZnCPO). In this case, the hybrid system behaves as a photoactive CORMA, retaining most of the potentially toxic decarbonylation fragments. These examples showed that porous frameworks with an exceptionally high surface-to-volume ratio allow (i) elevated CO payloads, (ii) trapping of the decarbonylation products generated after activation, and (iii) tuning of the CO delivery kinetics. Additionally, both particle size and morphology of MOFs can be controlled through different synthetic methodologies (e.g., mechanochemistry, ultrasound-assisted synthesis, and microemulsion synthesis). Among them, conventional solvothermal synthesis, assisted by the coordination modulation method (CMM), is a relatively simple and versatile strategy based on the use of capping reagents to modulate the crystal growth process. In this regard, particularly interesting is the abovementioned pioneering work of Furukawa et al., which focused on the influence of particle size over the CO-releasing properties of the CORMA MnBr­(bpydc)­(CO)3@UiO-67 (bpydc = 5,5′-dicarboxylate-2,2′-bipyridine).

elements.content: Taking into account this background, in this work, we show the feasibility to control the particle size and morphology in [Al­(OH)­(SDC)] n (H2SDC: 4,4′-stilbenedicarboxylic acid) (CYCU-3) by means of CMM. With this aim, we screened different reagent concentrations and modulator/ligand ratios. As a result, CYCU-3 materials with different particle features were isolated, including a new crystalline phase (CYCU-3′ 50_50), for which a structural model based on a defective and more dense structure than pristine CYCU-3 was proposed. Then, taking into account that CYCU-3 is composed by low-toxic Al­(III) ions and that its structure is based on one-dimensional (1D) mesopores (∼3 nm) that are able to host bulky molecules, we decided to use it as a platform to obtain new CORMAs. Thus, the nontoxic air-stable CORM ALF794 (Mo­(CNCMe2CO2H)3(CO)3), which has demonstrated efficacy in an animal model of acute liver failure, and can also be activated by light, was selected as a model drug to be loaded in three CYCU-3 materials. The influence of structure, crystal size, and morphology over the resulting CO-releasing properties, including payload, CO delivery, and matrix stability was also evaluated ().

With this aim, we screened different reagent concentrations and modulator/ligand ratios. As a result, CYCU-3 materials with different particle features were isolated, including a new crystalline phase (CYCU-3' 50_50), for which a structural model based on a defective and more dense structure than pristine CYCU-3 was proposed. elements.content: All chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. The CORM ALF794 [Mo­(CO)3(CNCMe2CO2H)3] (CNCMe2CO2H = tris­(2-isocyano-2-methyl propionic acid) was provided by Proterris (Portugal) Lda.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. The CORM ALF794 [Mo(CO)3(CNCMe2CO2H)3] (CNCMe2CO2H = tris(2-isocyano-2-methyl propionic acid) was provided by Proterris (Portugal) Lda.

elements.content: Several screenings were carried out to evaluate the influence of the synthetic conditions, namely reagent concentration and modulator/ligand ratio, over the particle properties in CYCU-3. In a typical reaction, an equimolar mixture of Al­(NO3)3·9H2O and H2SDC (with the concentrations varying from 20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 mM) in 750 μL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was mixed with a modulator (acetic acid-to-ligand ratio used: 0–1, 5–1, 20–1, and 50–1) and placed in a 1 mL Teflon-lined reactor. The slurry was heated at 190 °C for 72 h and cooled down to room temperature in 6 h. The resulting white solid was washed with DMF (3 × 1 mL), collected by centrifugation (10 min/3500 rpm), and dried at 90 °C under vacuum. As a result, 20 new materials were isolated [namely, CYCU-3 x_y, x: reagent concentration (mM), y: modulator/ligand ratio] and characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). From this preliminary screening, three of these materials (CYCU-3 20_0, CYCU-3 50_5, and CYCU-3′ 50_50) were selected and scaled up to study their potential properties as CORMAs (see the section).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of CYCU-3 Materials [Al(OH)(SDC)] n  (H2SDC: 4,4'-Stilbenedicarboxylic Acid)

Several screenings were carried out to evaluate the influence of the synthetic conditions, namely reagent concentration and modulator/ligand ratio, over the particle properties in CYCU-3. In a typical reaction, an equimolar mixture of Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O and H2SDC (with the concentrations varying from 20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 mM) in 750 μL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was mixed with a modulator (acetic acid-to-ligand ratio used: 0-1, 5-1, 20-1, and 50-1) and placed in a 1 mL Teflon-lined reactor. The slurry was heated at 190 °C for 72 h and cooled down to room temperature in 6 h. The resulting white solid was washed with DMF (3 × 1 mL), collected by centrifugation (10 min/3500 rpm), and dried at 90 °C under vacuum. As a result, 20 new materials were isolated [namely, CYCU-3 x_y, x: reagent concentration (mM), y: modulator/ligand ratio] and characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). From this preliminary screening, three of these materials (CYCU-3 20_0, CYCU-3 50_5, and CYCU-3' 50_50) were selected and scaled up to study their potential properties as CORMAs (see the  section).

elements.content: A suspension of 75 mg (0.2 mmol) of Al­(NO3)3·9H2O and 53.6 mg (0.2 mmol) of H2SDC in 10 mL of DMF was transferred to a 23 mL Teflon-lined reactor. The slurry was heated at 190 °C for 72 h and cooled down to room temperature in 6 h. The white solid was washed with DMF (3 × 10 mL), collected by centrifugation (10 min/3500 rpm), and dried at room temperature. The as-synthetized material was further washed to remove the potential unreacted ligand, which could be trapped inside the cavities. Thus, the corresponding solid was suspended in DMF (5 mg/mL), heated in a microwave-assisted reactor (50 °C, 15 min), and collected by centrifugation (10 min/3500 rpm). This process was done in triplicate. Anal. Calcd for CYCU-3 20_0 [Al­(OH)­(C16O4H10)]­(H2O)1.1(C3H7NO)0.1: N, 0.42; C, 58.03; H, 4.15. Found: N, 0.39; C, 60.11; H, 4.24. Residue (Al2O3) (calc./exp.): 16.13/15.88%.
elements.clean_text:
Scale-up Synthesis of CYCU-3 20_0

A suspension of 75 mg (0.2 mmol) of Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O and 53.6 mg (0.2 mmol) of H2SDC in 10 mL of DMF was transferred to a 23 mL Teflon-lined reactor. The slurry was heated at 190 °C for 72 h and cooled down to room temperature in 6 h. The white solid was washed with DMF (3 × 10 mL), collected by centrifugation (10 min/3500 rpm), and dried at room temperature. The as-synthetized material was further washed to remove the potential unreacted ligand, which could be trapped inside the cavities. Thus, the corresponding solid was suspended in DMF (5 mg/mL), heated in a microwave-assisted reactor (50 °C, 15 min), and collected by centrifugation (10 min/3500 rpm). This process was done in triplicate. Anal. Calcd for CYCU-3 20_0 [Al(OH)(C16O4H10)](H2O)1.1(C3H7NO)0.1: N, 0.42; C, 58.03; H, 4.15. Found: N, 0.39; C, 60.11; H, 4.24. Residue (Al2O3) (calc./exp.): 16.13/15.88%.

elements.content: The material CYCU-3 50_5 was prepared and isolated following the same procedure as that for CYCU-3 20_0. In this case, a suspension of 187.6 mg (0.5 mmol) of Al­(NO3)3·9H2O and 134.1 mg (0.5 mmol) of H2SDC in 9.86 mL of DMF was mixed with 0.14 mL (2.5 mmol) of acetic acid. Anal. Calcd for CYCU-3 50_5 [Al­(OH)­(C16O4H10)0.75(CH3COO)0.5]­(H2O)1.5(C3H7NO)0.18: N, 0.80; C, 51.89; H, 4.59. Found: N, 0.77; C, 51.31; H, 4.35. Residue (Al2O3) (calc./exp.): 16.27/18.22%.

elements.content: Prior to CORM loading, the selected CYCU-3 and CYCU-3′ matrixes were outgassed (150 °C, 10–4 bar) for 24 h. Under these conditions, the complete removal of the solvent guest molecules was achieved, and the empty pores ready for drug adsorption were obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Evacuation/Activation of CYCU-3 and CYCU-3' Materials

Prior to CORM loading, the selected CYCU-3 and CYCU-3' matrixes were outgassed (150 °C, 10-4 bar) for 24 h. Under these conditions, the complete removal of the solvent guest molecules was achieved, and the empty pores ready for drug adsorption were obtained.

elements.content: The loading of the CORM inside the pores of the selected CYCU-3 matrixes, namely CYCU-3 20_0, CYCU-3 50_5, and CYCU-3′ 50_50, was carried out by solid–liquid impregnation at room temperature. In a typical procedure, 10 mL of the methanol solution of ALF794 (100 mg, 0.19 mmol) was added to a suspension of a previously activated CYCU-3 matrix (100 mg in 10 mL of MeOH). The mixture was stirred until complete evaporation of the solvent (ca. 10 h). Then, the solid was washed with methanol (3 × 10 mL), collected by centrifugation (3500 rpm/10 min), and dried at room temperature. Following the same procedure, additional experiments in the absence of ALF794 (100 mg of CYCU-3 matrix in 20 mL of MeOH) were also performed to evaluate the stability of the three selected matrixes during the impregnation process. All manipulations were carried out in darkness to avoid the undesirable photoactivation of the CORM.
elements.clean_text:
Loading of ALF794 into CYCU-3 Matrixes

The loading of the CORM inside the pores of the selected CYCU-3 matrixes, namely CYCU-3 20_0, CYCU-3 50_5, and CYCU-3' 50_50, was carried out by solid-liquid impregnation at room temperature. In a typical procedure, 10 mL of the methanol solution of ALF794 (100 mg, 0.19 mmol) was added to a suspension of a previously activated CYCU-3 matrix (100 mg in 10 mL of MeOH). The mixture was stirred until complete evaporation of the solvent (ca. 10 h). Then, the solid was washed with methanol (3 × 10 mL), collected by centrifugation (3500 rpm/10 min), and dried at room temperature. Following the same procedure, additional experiments in the absence of ALF794 (100 mg of CYCU-3 matrix in 20 mL of MeOH) were also performed to evaluate the stability of the three selected matrixes during the impregnation process. All manipulations were carried out in darkness to avoid the undesirable photoactivation of the CORM.

elements.content:
XR fluorescence (XRF) of ALF794@CYCU-3 20_0. Mo/Al molar ratio = 0.14. Residue (exp.): 19.34%.

XRF of ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5. Mo/Al molar ratio = 0.20. Residue [(Al2O3)0.5(MoO2)0.20] (calc./exp.): 18.87/20.40%.

XRF of ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50. Mo/Al molar ratio = 0.19. Residue [(Al2O3)0.5(MoO2)0.19] (calc./exp.): 19.85/18.79%.

CO Detection in the Solid State

The sample suspended in pentane was repeatedly spin-coated on a glass substrate. The weight of the sample was accurately determined using a precision scale (typical weights: 0.9–1.1 mg). The sample was placed in a custom-made chamber with a glass window on the top and irradiated with a 300 W xenon lamp (Asahi Spectra Max-303 equipped with a 235–385 nm ultraviolet module and ×1.0 collimator lens). The light intensity was 50 mW cm–2. The released CO gas from the CORMA was carried to the CO detector (HALO 3 TM trace gas analyzer from Tiger Optics) by N2 flow (500 mL min–1 flow rate).

elements.content: To evaluate the ability of the hybrid materials to retain the metal fragments inside the pores, suspensions of ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 (24 mg L–1) and ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50 (15 mg L–1) in 10 mM PBS were prepared. The samples were incubated at 37 °C under visible light for 6, 24, and 72 h (using a fluorescent lamp, luminous flux: 600 lm; color temperature: 4000 K; distance between the lamp and cuvette: 5 cm). At each time, the supernatant was collected by centrifugation (3500 rpm/10 min) and filtered off (nylon filter membrane, 0.2 μm). The concentration of Mo was quantified by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP–OES).
elements.clean_text:
Leaching Studies of ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3' 50_50 in Phosphate-Buffered Saline (PBS) under Visible Light

To evaluate the ability of the hybrid materials to retain the metal fragments inside the pores, suspensions of ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 (24 mg L-1) and ALF794@CYCU-3' 50_50 (15 mg L-1) in 10 mM PBS were prepared. The samples were incubated at 37 °C under visible light for 6, 24, and 72 h (using a fluorescent lamp, luminous flux: 600 lm; color temperature: 4000 K; distance between the lamp and cuvette: 5 cm). At each time, the supernatant was collected by centrifugation (3500 rpm/10 min) and filtered off (nylon filter membrane, 0.2 μm). The concentration of Mo was quantified by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES).

elements.content: To analyze the nature of the isolated CYCU-3′ x_50 materials, we carried out a structural study of CYCU-3′ 50_50 by CRED. With this aim, the sample was dispersed in acetone, and a droplet of the suspension was transferred onto a carbon-coated copper grid. Three-dimensional (3D) CRED data of CYCU-3′ 50_50 were collected at 200 kV on a JEOL JEM2100 transmission electron microscope using a Timepix pixel detector QTPX-262k (512 × 512 pixels, pixel size 55 μm, Amsterdam Sci. Ins.). A single-tilt tomography sample holder was used for the data collection, which could tilt from −70° to +70°. The electron beam was fully spread and covered the whole phosphorus screen. The aperture used for the CRED data collection was about 1.0 μm in diameter. The electron diffraction (ED) data were acquired in a selected area using a continuous ED mode. The speed of the goniometer tilt was 0.074°/s, and the exposure time was 50 ms/frame. A total of 924 ED frames were collected within 1 min, covering a tilt range from 50.6° to −16.4°. The 3D reciprocal lattice of CYCU-3′ 50_50 was reconstructed from the ED frames using REDa data processing software package.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Characterization of CYCU-3' 50_50 by Continuous Rotation Electron Diffraction (CRED)

To analyze the nature of the isolated CYCU-3' x_50 materials, we carried out a structural study of CYCU-3' 50_50 by CRED. With this aim, the sample was dispersed in acetone, and a droplet of the suspension was transferred onto a carbon-coated copper grid. Three-dimensional (3D) CRED data of CYCU-3' 50_50 were collected at 200 kV on a JEOL JEM2100 transmission electron microscope using a Timepix pixel detector QTPX-262k (512 × 512 pixels, pixel size 55 μm, Amsterdam Sci. Ins.). A single-tilt tomography sample holder was used for the data collection, which could tilt from -70° to +70°. The electron beam was fully spread and covered the whole phosphorus screen. The aperture used for the CRED data collection was about 1.0 μm in diameter. The electron diffraction (ED) data were acquired in a selected area using a continuous ED mode. The speed of the goniometer tilt was 0.074°/s, and the exposure time was 50 ms/frame. A total of 924 ED frames were collected within 1 min, covering a tilt range from 50.6° to -16.4°. The 3D reciprocal lattice of CYCU-3' 50_50 was reconstructed from the ED frames using REDa data processing software package.

elements.content: The PXRD data were collected on a Bruker D2-PHASE diffractometer (2θ) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) and a LYNXEYE detector (University of Granada), or on a SmartLab Rigaku diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) (WPI-iCEMs, Kyoto University). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Mettler Toledo TGA/differential scanning calorimetry STAR system under an oxygen flow (20 mL min–1) running from room temperature (RT) to 900 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C min–1 (CIC, University of Granada). The N2 adsorption isotherms were measured at 77 K on a Micromeritics TriStar 3000 volumetric instrument. Prior to isotherm acquisition, the matrixes were activated and outgassed (150 °C, 10–4 bar) for 24 h (University of Granada). The infrared spectra were collected in a Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrophotometer Bruker Tensor 27, using KBr as the dispersing agent (University of Granada). Elemental (C, H, N, S) analyses were obtained by a Flash EA1112 CHNS-O instrument (Centre of Scientific Instrumentation, University of Jaén). The molar ratio between Al and Mo was determined via XRF spectrometry in a Rigaku NEX CG equipped with a palladium tube as the source of radiation. The XRF measurements were performed onto the powder samples. The ICP–OES analysis was carried out using an OPTIMA 7300 DV spectrometer (SCAI, University of Málaga). The CRED data of CYCU-3′ 50_50 were collected at 200 kV on a JEOL JEM2100 transmission electron microscope using a Timepix pixel detector QTPX-262k (Stockholm University). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mapping were performed using a HAADF FEI Titan G2 microscope, with an FEI system to carry out chemical analysis (CIC, University of Granada), whereas the SEM images were recorded using a JEOL-JSM-7001F microscope (WPI-iCEMs, Kyoto University). In both cases, the samples were prepared by dispersing a small amount of the material (3 mg) in absolute ethanol (1 mL), followed by sonication for 10 min and deposition on a copper grid (TEM) or on a piece of glass (SEM). In the latter case, the sample was coated with osmium before acquisition.

elements.content: We selected the porous metal–organic network [Al­(OH)­(SDC)] n (H2SDC: 4,4′-stilbenedicarboxylic acid) (CYCU-3) to modulate the size and morphology of its particles by using CMM. The use of this strategy allows the preparation of materials with different particle features, which may have influence on the final properties of the prepared CORMAs (e.g., drug cargo, stability, and CO delivery properties). Regarding CYCU-3, it was first synthesized by Lin et al., and its structure is based on the Al­(III) ions bound to the dicarboxylate organic spacers SDC and the hydroxide anions acting as bridges, leading to the Kagomé topology. As a result, two types of cavities are formed, namely, hexagonal mesopores (∼3 nm) and triangular micropores (∼1.4 nm). Thus, both size and spatial distribution of the CYCU-3 mesopores, leading to 1D channels along the c axis, will favor the incorporation and diffusion of bulky guest molecules, making this MOF a suitable vehicle for the loading and release of CORMs. Regarding toxicity issues, the low toxicity of aluminum ions is well-known (oral LD50 for Al­(III) in rats: 286 mg kg–1; daily Al­(III) requirement in humans: 7.2 mg/day), whereas, to the best of our knowledge, no biological investigations related to CYCU-3 or 4,4′-stilbenedicarboxylic acid have been reported to date. However, a recent study by Fairen-Jimenez et al. pointed out a certain in vitro cytotoxicity of a Zr­(IV) MOF-containing 4,4′-stilbenedicarboxylate ligands. Noteworthy, to prepare CYCU-3 materials, CMM was selected as the synthetic strategy, mainly for two reasons: (i) the moderate-to-harsh reaction conditions (solvothermal synthesis at 190 °C) needed for the preparation of CYCU-3 prevent the use of other synthetic routes, such as mechanochemical or ultrasonic-assisted methods and (ii) the structure of this MOF exhibits two different metal–ligand interaction modes (Al–OH and Al–SDC), allowing an anisotropic modulation during the crystallization process. In this sense, acetic acid was selected as the modulator because it is miscible with DMF, the solvent used in the preparation of CYCU-3, and can compete with the carboxylic organic spacer H2SDC to coordinate to the Al­(III) metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Control on Size and Morphology of [Al(OH)(SDC)] n  (CYCU-3) Particles

We selected the porous metal-organic network [Al(OH)(SDC)] n  (H2SDC: 4,4'-stilbenedicarboxylic acid) (CYCU-3) to modulate the size and morphology of its particles by using CMM. The use of this strategy allows the preparation of materials with different particle features, which may have influence on the final properties of the prepared CORMAs (e.g., drug cargo, stability, and CO delivery properties). Regarding CYCU-3, it was first synthesized by Lin et al., and its structure is based on the Al(III) ions bound to the dicarboxylate organic spacers SDC and the hydroxide anions acting as bridges, leading to the Kagomé topology. As a result, two types of cavities are formed, namely, hexagonal mesopores (~3 nm) and triangular micropores (~1.4 nm). Thus, both size and spatial distribution of the CYCU-3 mesopores, leading to 1D channels along the c axis, will favor the incorporation and diffusion of bulky guest molecules, making this MOF a suitable vehicle for the loading and release of CORMs. Regarding toxicity issues, the low toxicity of aluminum ions is well-known (oral LD50 for Al(III) in rats: 286 mg kg-1; daily Al(III) requirement in humans: 7.2 mg/day), whereas, to the best of our knowledge, no biological investigations related to CYCU-3 or 4,4'-stilbenedicarboxylic acid have been reported to date. However, a recent study by Fairen-Jimenez et al. pointed out a certain in vitro cytotoxicity of a Zr(IV) MOF-containing 4,4'-stilbenedicarboxylate ligands. Noteworthy, to prepare CYCU-3 materials, CMM was selected as the synthetic strategy, mainly for two reasons: (i) the moderate-to-harsh reaction conditions (solvothermal synthesis at 190 °C) needed for the preparation of CYCU-3 prevent the use of other synthetic routes, such as mechanochemical or ultrasonic-assisted methods and (ii) the structure of this MOF exhibits two different metal-ligand interaction modes (Al-OH and Al-SDC), allowing an anisotropic modulation during the crystallization process. In this sense, acetic acid was selected as the modulator because it is miscible with DMF, the solvent used in the preparation of CYCU-3, and can compete with the carboxylic organic spacer H2SDC to coordinate to the Al(III) metal ions.

elements.content: In the absence of a modulator, different equimolar amounts (20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 mM) of aluminum­(III) nitrate and 4,4′-stilbenedicarboxylic acid were reacted in DMF, and the mixtures were heated up to 190 °C for 3 days. In all cases, a white precipitate was obtained, which was thoroughly washed with DMF and allowed to dry at 90 °C under vacuum (see the ). As a result, five samples were successfully isolated, namely, CYCU-3 20_0, CYCU-3 30_0, CYCU-3 40_0, CYCU-3 50_0, and CYCU-3 60_0 [CYCU-3 x_y, x: reagent concentration (mM), y: modulator/ligand ratio]. The crystallinity of the abovementioned materials was analyzed by PXRD measurements. As it is shown in , when the most diluted concentration of reagents was used (20 mM), a poorly crystalline material (CYCU-3 20_0) was obtained. In contrast, more crystalline solids were recovered when using higher reagent concentrations (30–60 mM).
elements.clean_text:
Influence of Reagent Concentration

In the absence of a modulator, different equimolar amounts (20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 mM) of aluminum(III) nitrate and 4,4'-stilbenedicarboxylic acid were reacted in DMF, and the mixtures were heated up to 190 °C for 3 days. In all cases, a white precipitate was obtained, which was thoroughly washed with DMF and allowed to dry at 90 °C under vacuum (see the ). As a result, five samples were successfully isolated, namely, CYCU-3 20_0, CYCU-3 30_0, CYCU-3 40_0, CYCU-3 50_0, and CYCU-3 60_0 [CYCU-3 x_y, x: reagent concentration (mM), y: modulator/ligand ratio]. The crystallinity of the abovementioned materials was analyzed by PXRD measurements. As it is shown in , when the most diluted concentration of reagents was used (20 mM), a poorly crystalline material (CYCU-3 20_0) was obtained. In contrast, more crystalline solids were recovered when using higher reagent concentrations (30-60 mM).

elements.content: Both particle size and morphology of these five materials were examined by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). The FESEM images showed that CYCU-3 20_0 is composed by particles in the nanometric range (<100 nm), with a pseudospherical morphology. Indeed, these particle features are in agreement with the PXRD pattern of this system that showed wide and low-intense reflections characteristic of the nanometric materials. Besides, the rest of the solids comprised mainly particles with bar-like morphology in the micrometric range. It should be noted that when higher concentrations of the reactants are used, more heterogeneous materials including agglomerates are obtained.
elements.clean_text: Both particle size and morphology of these five materials were examined by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). The FESEM images showed that CYCU-3 20_0 is composed by particles in the nanometric range (<100 nm), with a pseudospherical morphology. Indeed, these particle features are in agreement with the PXRD pattern of this system that showed wide and low-intense reflections characteristic of the nanometric materials. Besides, the rest of the solids comprised mainly particles with bar-like morphology in the micrometric range. It should be noted that when higher concentrations of the reactants are used, more heterogeneous materials including agglomerates are obtained.

elements.content: After analyzing the influence of reagent concentrations, different acetic acid/ligand molar ratios (y = 5, 20, and 50) were tested, maintaining the previously selected reagent concentrations (20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 mM). Thus, other 15 new CYCU-3 materials were obtained and characterized. On one hand, the PXRD studies revealed that increasing amounts of modulator do not improve the crystallinity of the resulting CYCU-3 20_y materials (Figure S1). On the other hand, the crystallinity of the rest of the isolated solids highly depends on the modulator ratio, showing a similar trend for the tested reagent concentrations (30, 40, 50, and 60 mM). In fact, no changes in the PXRD patterns, in comparison to pristine CYCU-3 published by Lin et al. (CYCU-3 40_5), were observed when the acetic acid/ligand molar ratios of 5 or 20 were used. However, the use of acetic acid with 50 times greater concentration than that of the ligand always yielded materials with low crystallinity (CYCU-3′ 30_50, CYCU-3′ 40_50, CYCU-3′ 50_50, and CYCU-3′ 60_50) (). In addition, the abovementioned systems showed a slight displacement of the most intense reflection to a lower angle (from 2θ = 6.02° to 5.62°), which might be indicative of the formation of a new phase (see discussion below). Furthermore, the FESEM images confirmed that when the modulator ratio is increased, longer needles are obtained in all cases (Figure S2). This fact can be explained taking into account the structure of CYCU-3, in which the Al­(III) ions are connected through OH bridges, giving rise to 1D chains extended along the c axis. Additionally, these secondary building units are linked through the SDC linkers, leading to the formation of monodimensional channel structures with hexagonal and triangular shapes. Thus, the addition of a modulator has no influence on the Al–OH interactions and, therefore, does not limit the crystal growth along the c axis. Nevertheless, the acetic acid molecules can compete with the organic spacers to coordinate to the Al­(III) ions, modifying the coordination equilibrium and, consequently, increasing the length/width ratio of the resulting particles. Indeed, this hypothesis is confirmed by the presence of a small amount of acetate, mainly distributed along the surface of the particles, in the corresponding elemental analysis of CYCU-3 50_5 and CYCU-3′ 50_50 materials.
elements.clean_text:
Influence of Modulator Concentration

After analyzing the influence of reagent concentrations, different acetic acid/ligand molar ratios (y = 5, 20, and 50) were tested, maintaining the previously selected reagent concentrations (20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 mM). Thus, other 15 new CYCU-3 materials were obtained and characterized. On one hand, the PXRD studies revealed that increasing amounts of modulator do not improve the crystallinity of the resulting CYCU-3 20_y materials (Figure S1). On the other hand, the crystallinity of the rest of the isolated solids highly depends on the modulator ratio, showing a similar trend for the tested reagent concentrations (30, 40, 50, and 60 mM). In fact, no changes in the PXRD patterns, in comparison to pristine CYCU-3 published by Lin et al. (CYCU-3 40_5), were observed when the acetic acid/ligand molar ratios of 5 or 20 were used. However, the use of acetic acid with 50 times greater concentration than that of the ligand always yielded materials with low crystallinity (CYCU-3' 30_50, CYCU-3' 40_50, CYCU-3' 50_50, and CYCU-3' 60_50) (). In addition, the abovementioned systems showed a slight displacement of the most intense reflection to a lower angle (from 2θ = 6.02° to 5.62°), which might be indicative of the formation of a new phase (see discussion below). Furthermore, the FESEM images confirmed that when the modulator ratio is increased, longer needles are obtained in all cases (Figure S2). This fact can be explained taking into account the structure of CYCU-3, in which the Al(III) ions are connected through OH bridges, giving rise to 1D chains extended along the c axis. Additionally, these secondary building units are linked through the SDC linkers, leading to the formation of monodimensional channel structures with hexagonal and triangular shapes. Thus, the addition of a modulator has no influence on the Al-OH interactions and, therefore, does not limit the crystal growth along the c axis. Nevertheless, the acetic acid molecules can compete with the organic spacers to coordinate to the Al(III) ions, modifying the coordination equilibrium and, consequently, increasing the length/width ratio of the resulting particles. Indeed, this hypothesis is confirmed by the presence of a small amount of acetate, mainly distributed along the surface of the particles, in the corresponding elemental analysis of CYCU-3 50_5 and CYCU-3' 50_50 materials.

elements.content: As mentioned before, to further clarify the nature of the isolated CYCU-3′ x_50 materials, we modeled the CYCU-3′ 50_50 structure by CRED. For this purpose, the images of the CYCU-3′ 50_50 material were obtained using a transmission electron microscope, and the ED data of a selected area were recorded. The crystals have long ribbon-like morphology (Figure S3), as previously observed in the corresponding SEM images (Figure S2). The 3D reciprocal lattice of CYCU-3′ 50_50 was reconstructed from the ED frames (Figure S4) and used for the determination of the unit cell parameters (a = 16.35 Å, b = 62.15 Å, c = 6.73 Å, α = 89.7°, β = 94.5°, and γ = 88.1°). These values showed some differences, particularly in the a-axis and β angle, in comparison to those of pristine CYCU-3 (a = 34.067 Å, b = 60.07 Å, c = 6.312 Å, α = 90.0°, β = 90.0°, and γ = 90.0°), which may suggest that CYCU-3′ 50_50 is a new structure of the original MOF. Unfortunately, the CYCU-3′ 50_50 structure is disordered along the b axis, as severe diffraction streaks along this direction were observed in the reconstructed 3D reciprocal lattice (Figure S4). Thus, this disorder, together with the flexible behavior of the crystals (bending, twisting, and coiling) (Figure S4a–c), avoids a direct structure solution using the CRED data. For this reason, the Pawley fit was applied to the PXRD data to confirm and refine the unit cell parameters (Figure S5). The refinement was conducted using a Pearson VII-type peak profile function, followed by the refinement of the unit cells and zero-shift. The R-value was converged to R p = 0.110, R wp = 0.0634, R exp = 0.267, and goodness of fit (GOF) = 0.237. The high R exp and low GOF values are due to the broad peaks caused by the disorder and preferred orientation. The new refined unit cell parameters (a = 16.971 Å, b = 64.039 Å, c = 6.694 Å, α = 90.0°, β = 94.447°, and γ = 90°) confirmed that CYCU-3′ 50_50 changes to a new structure. On the basis of these data, an average structural model for CYCU-3′ 50_50 was built (Figure S6). The crystal structure is based on the corner-shared AlO6 octahedra, leading to 1D chains, as in CYCU-3. However, there are more Al chains in the unit cell of CYCU-3′ 50_50 than in CYCU-3, as the a axis of the former is halved (a = 16.35 and 34.067 Å, respectively). As a consequence, the CYCU-3′ 50_50 framework is 61% more dense than pristine CYCU-3 (0.731 and 0.453 g/cm–3, respectively), resulting in a material with a lower Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area (see the preparation of hybrid materials for more details). In addition, the new CYCU-3′ 50_50 structure has 1D channels that represent the small pores of CYCU-3. On the other hand, the disordered nature of the CYCU-3′ 50_50 crystals (Figure S4) could be caused by the coordination of acetate instead of the SDC ligands to the Al centers, not only in the crystal surface but also in the inner structure, creating defects (a). This hypothesis is further supported by the elemental analysis, in which a high acetate/SDC ratio of 1.63 was found. To confirm the structural model, ED pattern simulation was applied (b). The experimental ED pattern of CYCU-3′ 50_50 (b-I) was compared with the CYCU-3′ 50_50 average model (b-III) and the simulated ED pattern of CYCU-3 (b-II, generated from the previously reported CYCU-3 structure). Extra diffraction rows are observed in b-I, which agrees well with the pattern from the CYCU-3′ 50_50 average model (b-II), whereas the simulated ED pattern of CYCU-3 lacks these rows (b-III). This suggests that the proposed model of CYCU-3′ 50_50 is correct, and it is of a different phase from the original CYCU-3. However, the high degree of disorder found in CYCU-3′ 50_50 may be caused by the previously mentioned ligand defects and/or by the missing AlO6 chains.
elements.clean_text:

However, the high degree of disorder found in CYCU-3' 50_50 may be caused by the previously mentioned ligand defects and/or by the missing AlO6 chains.

elements.clean_text:
Preparation of ALF794@CYCU-3 Hybrid Materials

In view of the previously discussed results, we used three CYCU-3 materials with different particle features for the loading of the photoactive CORM ALF794 [Mo(CNCMe2CO2H)3(CO)3] (CNCMe2CO2H = 2-isocyano-2-methyl propionic acid). The potential influence that the particle size and morphology exerted on the properties of the resulting ALF794@CYCU-3 CORMAs was analyzed. In particular, we selected: (i) CYCU-3 20_0, comprising pseudospherical nanoparticles in the nanometric range (~100 nm); (ii) CYCU-3 50_5, formed by bar-type particles with heterogeneous size; and (iii) CYCU-3' 50_50, which presents micrometric needles with a distorted and defective structure (). These materials were scaled up, and an exhaustive washing process was performed to remove the unreacted ligand molecules that may be trapped inside the cavities of the matrixes (see the ).

elements.content: SEM images of the selected CYCU-3 materials exhibiting: (a) pseudospherical nanoparticles of CYCU-3 20_0, (b) heterogeneous bar-like CYCU-3 50_5 particles, and (c) long CYCU-3′ 50_50 needles.
elements.clean_text: 4  SEM images of the selected CYCU-3 materials exhibiting: (a) pseudospherical nanoparticles of CYCU-3 20_0, (b) heterogeneous bar-like CYCU-3 50_5 particles, and (c) long CYCU-3' 50_50 needles.

elements.content: Afterward, the matrixes were activated (150 °C under vacuum for 24 h), and the TGA measurements of the desolvated materials were recorded, confirming that, in all cases, the CYCU-3 materials were free of ligands and/or solvent molecules, as no mass loss was observed up to ∼350 °C (Figure S7). Regarding thermal stability, the decomposition temperature increases with particle size (ca. 351, 408, and 473 °C for CYCU-3 20_0, CYCU-3 50_5, and CYCU-3′ 50_50, respectively). In addition, we evaluated the permanent porosity of these materials by measuring the nitrogen adsorption isotherms at 77 K (Figure S8). In all cases, the isotherm profiles were characteristic of the materials with both micro- and mesopores. Besides, CYCU-3 20_0 and CYCU-3 50_5 exhibited a similar BET surface areas (2225 and 2270 m2 g–1, respectively) than that previously reported for pristine CYCU-3 (2760 m2 g–1), whereas the adsorption capacity of CYCU-3′ 50_50 was markedly lower (265 m2 g–1), probably because of its more dense framework compared to that of pristine CYCU-3 (see the structural studies for more details). The pore size distribution of the different porous frameworks was also determined (Figure S9).

Regarding thermal stability, the decomposition temperature increases with particle size (ca. 351, 408, and 473 °C for CYCU-3 20_0, CYCU-3 50_5, and CYCU-3' 50_50, respectively). The pore size distribution of the different porous frameworks was also determined (Figure S9).

elements.content: Once the selected CYCU-3 materials were characterized, we carried out the diffusion of the CO-prodrug by means of a solid–liquid impregnation strategy. All materials were suspended in a methanolic solution of ALF794, and the mixtures were stirred until complete evaporation of the solvent to force the incorporation of the drug into the pores (see the ). The resulting solids were thoroughly washed with MeOH and allowed to dry at RT. Infrared spectroscopy first confirmed the successful loading of ALF794 into the cavities of the three selected porous matrixes ( and S10). The characteristic stretching CO bands of ALF794 appeared slightly shifted in the hybrid materials compared to the pristine CORM. This small displacement is due to the confinement of the CORM molecules inside the pores, as previously reported in the literature.

elements.content: The quantification of ALF794 loading was estimated by XRF analysis. In all cases, similar Mo/Al molar ratios were found (0.14, 0.20, and 0.19 for ALF794@CYCU-3 20_0, ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5, and ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50, respectively), suggesting that the particle size/morphology of the synthesized matrixes does not have an appreciable influence on the total amount of loaded CO-prodrug. Moreover, the presence of defects in the CYCU-3′ 50_50 structure seems to favor the inclusion of the CORM in the pore structure, leading to a payload similar to that found for the other two prepared materials, which exhibit significant higher BET surface areas (see above).

elements.content: The hybrid materials were also characterized by PXRD (Figure S11). Thus, the ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50 solids showed diffraction patterns similar to those of the corresponding empty matrixes, confirming their stability under the drug-loading conditions. On the contrary, the ALF794@CYCU-3 20_0 nanoparticles exhibited a slight degradation as two new reflections appeared in the PXRD pattern, attributed to the free H2SDC ligand. These results point toward a direct relationship between the particle size and chemical stability of the hybrid materials. For this reason, ALF794@CYCU-3 20_0 was not considered for further studies.

elements.content: To test the potential biological application as CORMAs of ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50, their photoinduced CO release properties were first investigated in solution (10 mM PBS, 37 °C) by UV–vis spectroscopy using the myoglobin assay. Although both the hybrid materials released appreciable amounts of CO (0.46 and 0.24 mmol of CO per mmol of CORM, respectively, upon 24 h of irradiation with visible light, Figure S12), molybdenum leaching was also detected (94 and 25%, respectively, after 6 h of incubation with no further leaching in the next 72 h) (Table S1). The high extent of metal leaching from ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 might be attributed to its smaller particle size, which unfortunately leads to a high degradation of the framework in PBS. In contrast, ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50 shows a significantly lower metal leaching (25% of Mo) related to its less porous structure and larger particle size. Taking into account the latter fact, ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50 is the only hybrid material that can be considered as a real CORMA in solution.
elements.clean_text:
Evaluation of ALF794@CYCU-3 Hybrid Materials as Potential CORMAs

To test the potential biological application as CORMAs of ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3' 50_50, their photoinduced CO release properties were first investigated in solution (10 mM PBS, 37 °C) by UV-vis spectroscopy using the myoglobin assay. Although both the hybrid materials released appreciable amounts of CO (0.46 and 0.24 mmol of CO per mmol of CORM, respectively, upon 24 h of irradiation with visible light, Figure S12), molybdenum leaching was also detected (94 and 25%, respectively, after 6 h of incubation with no further leaching in the next 72 h) (Table S1). The high extent of metal leaching from ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 might be attributed to its smaller particle size, which unfortunately leads to a high degradation of the framework in PBS. In contrast, ALF794@CYCU-3' 50_50 shows a significantly lower metal leaching (25% of Mo) related to its less porous structure and larger particle size. Taking into account the latter fact, ALF794@CYCU-3' 50_50 is the only hybrid material that can be considered as a real CORMA in solution.

elements.content: To further explore the ability of these hybrid systems as CORMAs, we decided to study their CO delivery properties in the solid state, envisaging their potential use for topical applications (i.e., anti-inflammatory bandages). In this context, the previously reported innovative application of photoactive CORMs for topical treatment of epidermal cancer should be highlighted. Indeed, CORM-2, [Ru2Cl4(CO)6], lotions were shown to reduce the acute and chronic inflammation and tumor multiplicity in hairless mice with induced photocarcinogenesis. Thus, an in-line CO detector was customized to measure the CO released from the ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50 solid matrixes (Figure S13). In particular, both hybrid materials were spin-coated and irradiated at 250–385 nm with 50 mW cm–2 of light power to promote the CO release. The delivered CO was transferred using N2 as the carrier gas to the in-line detector. The CO release efficiencies of the ALF794-loaded materials were compared to that of free CORM (). Thus, pristine ALF794 behaves also as a photoCORM in the solid state, releasing 0.42 mmol of CO per mmol of CORM after 220 min (photo-releasing efficiency: 42%). In addition, both hybrid materials retain the photoactive properties of the molybdenum tricarbonyl complex, showing an average CO delivery of 0.44 and 0.35 mmol of CO per mmol of CORM (44 and 35% of CO release efficiency) for ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50, respectively.

elements.content: In this work, we have used CMM to successfully prepare several CYCU-3 materials with different particle size and morphology, ranging from pseudospherical nanoparticles of ∼100 nm to elongated particles of several microns. Surprisingly, when we used a modulator concentration 50 times greater than that of the ligand, a new crystalline phase (CYCU-3′ 50_50) was obtained. In particular, the unit cell parameters and space group of CYCU-3′ 50_50 were determined from the CRED data, and the former were further refined against the PXRD data using the Pawley method, suggesting that CYCU-3′ 50_50 is probably an analogous structure of pristine CYCU-3. Unfortunately, the poor crystallinity of the material prevented a direct structure solution. For this reason, a possible structural model for CYCU-3′ 50_50 was built, and the corresponding simulated ED patterns fitted well with the experimental ones. In addition, we have loaded the bioactive CO-prodrug ALF794 in three selected CYCU-3 materials (CYCU-3 20_0, CYCU-3 50_5, and CYCU-3′ 50_50) and investigated the influence of the MOF features over the properties of the resulting CORMAs. We observed that the nanometric nature of CYCU-3 20_0 was responsible for the partial degradation of the matrix under the drug loading conditions. For this reason, this material was not considered for further studies. Regarding the ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50 hybrid materials showing particles in the micrometric range, CO delivery was evaluated in solution and in solid state, envisaging their potential use for topical therapeutic applications. Our results demonstrated that both hybrid materials retained the photoactive properties of pristine CORM, with ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50 exhibiting the highest retention of metal fragments in PBS reported to date for a MOF-based CO-releasing material, which makes it a real CORMA.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, we have used CMM to successfully prepare several CYCU-3 materials with different particle size and morphology, ranging from pseudospherical nanoparticles of ~100 nm to elongated particles of several microns. Surprisingly, when we used a modulator concentration 50 times greater than that of the ligand, a new crystalline phase (CYCU-3' 50_50) was obtained. In particular, the unit cell parameters and space group of CYCU-3' 50_50 were determined from the CRED data, and the former were further refined against the PXRD data using the Pawley method, suggesting that CYCU-3' 50_50 is probably an analogous structure of pristine CYCU-3. Unfortunately, the poor crystallinity of the material prevented a direct structure solution. For this reason, a possible structural model for CYCU-3' 50_50 was built, and the corresponding simulated ED patterns fitted well with the experimental ones. In addition, we have loaded the bioactive CO-prodrug ALF794 in three selected CYCU-3 materials (CYCU-3 20_0, CYCU-3 50_5, and CYCU-3' 50_50) and investigated the influence of the MOF features over the properties of the resulting CORMAs. We observed that the nanometric nature of CYCU-3 20_0 was responsible for the partial degradation of the matrix under the drug loading conditions. For this reason, this material was not considered for further studies. Regarding the ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3' 50_50 hybrid materials showing particles in the micrometric range, CO delivery was evaluated in solution and in solid state, envisaging their potential use for topical therapeutic applications. Our results demonstrated that both hybrid materials retained the photoactive properties of pristine CORM, with ALF794@CYCU-3' 50_50 exhibiting the highest retention of metal fragments in PBS reported to date for a MOF-based CO-releasing material, which makes it a real CORMA.

A suspension of 75 mg (0.2 mmol) of Al­(NO3)3·9H2O and 53.6 mg (0.2 mmol) of H2SDC in 10 mL of DMF was transferred to a 23 mL Teflon-lined reactor. The slurry was heated at 190 °C for 72 h and cooled down to room temperature in 6 h. The white solid was washed with DMF (3 × 10 mL), collected by centrifugation (10 min/3500 rpm), and dried at room temperature. The as-synthetized material was further washed to remove the potential unreacted ligand, which could be trapped inside the cavities. Thus, the corresponding solid was suspended in DMF (5 mg/mL), heated in a microwave-assisted reactor (50 °C, 15 min), and collected by centrifugation (10 min/3500 rpm). This process was done in triplicate. Anal. Calcd for CYCU-3 20_0 [Al­(OH)­(C16O4H10)]­(H2O)1.1(C3H7NO)0.1: N, 0.42; C, 58.03; H, 4.15. Found: N, 0.39; C, 60.11; H, 4.24. Residue (Al2O3) (calc./exp.): 16.13/15.88%.

Scale-up Synthesis of CYCU-3 50_5

The material CYCU-3 50_5 was prepared and isolated following the same procedure as that for CYCU-3 20_0. In this case, a suspension of 187.6 mg (0.5 mmol) of Al­(NO3)3·9H2O and 134.1 mg (0.5 mmol) of H2SDC in 9.86 mL of DMF was mixed with 0.14 mL (2.5 mmol) of acetic acid. Anal. Calcd for CYCU-3 50_5 [Al­(OH)­(C16O4H10)0.75(CH3COO)0.5]­(H2O)1.5(C3H7NO)0.18: N, 0.80; C, 51.89; H, 4.59. Found: N, 0.77; C, 51.31; H, 4.35. Residue (Al2O3) (calc./exp.): 16.27/18.22%.

Scale-up Synthesis of CYCU-3′ 50_50

The material CYCU-3′ 50_50 was prepared and isolated following the same procedure as that for CYCU-3 20_0. In this case, a suspension of 187.6 mg (0.5 mmol) of Al­(NO3)3·9H2O and 134.1 mg (0.5 mmol) of H2SDC in 8.6 mL of DMF was mixed with 1.4 mL (25 mmol) of acetic acid. Anal. Calcd for CYCU-3′ 50_50 [Al­(OH)­(C16O4H10)0.55(CH3COO)0.9]­(C3H7NO)0.04: N, 0.23; C, 52.23; H, 3.88. Found: N, 0.29; C, 52.73; H, 3.58. Residue (Al2O3) (calc./exp.): 20.68/22.10%.

cln_elements.content:
As mentioned before, to further clarify the nature of the isolated CYCU-3′ x_50 materials, we modeled the CYCU-3′ 50_50 structure by CRED. For this purpose, the images of the CYCU-3′ 50_50 material were obtained using a transmission electron microscope, and the ED data of a selected area were recorded. The crystals have long ribbon-like morphology (Figure S3), as previously observed in the corresponding SEM images (Figure S2). The 3D reciprocal lattice of CYCU-3′ 50_50 was reconstructed from the ED frames (Figure S4) and used for the determination of the unit cell parameters (a = 16.35 Å, b = 62.15 Å, c = 6.73 Å, α = 89.7°, β = 94.5°, and γ = 88.1°). These values showed some differences, particularly in the a-axis and β angle, in comparison to those of pristine CYCU-3 (a = 34.067 Å, b = 60.07 Å, c = 6.312 Å, α = 90.0°, β = 90.0°, and γ = 90.0°), which may suggest that CYCU-3′ 50_50 is a new structure of the original MOF. Unfortunately, the CYCU-3′ 50_50 structure is disordered along the b axis, as severe diffraction streaks along this direction were observed in the reconstructed 3D reciprocal lattice (Figure S4). Thus, this disorder, together with the flexible behavior of the crystals (bending, twisting, and coiling) (Figure S4a–c), avoids a direct structure solution using the CRED data. For this reason, the Pawley fit was applied to the PXRD data to confirm and refine the unit cell parameters (Figure S5). The refinement was conducted using a Pearson VII-type peak profile function, followed by the refinement of the unit cells and zero-shift. The R-value was converged to R p = 0.110, R wp = 0.0634, R exp = 0.267, and goodness of fit (GOF) = 0.237. The high R exp and low GOF values are due to the broad peaks caused by the disorder and preferred orientation. The new refined unit cell parameters (a = 16.971 Å, b = 64.039 Å, c = 6.694 Å, α = 90.0°, β = 94.447°, and γ = 90°) confirmed that CYCU-3′ 50_50 changes to a new structure. On the basis of these data, an average structural model for CYCU-3′ 50_50 was built (Figure S6). The crystal structure is based on the corner-shared AlO6 octahedra, leading to 1D chains, as in CYCU-3. However, there are more Al chains in the unit cell of CYCU-3′ 50_50 than in CYCU-3, as the a axis of the former is halved (a = 16.35 and 34.067 Å, respectively). As a consequence, the CYCU-3′ 50_50 framework is 61% more dense than pristine CYCU-3 (0.731 and 0.453 g/cm–3, respectively), resulting in a material with a lower Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area (see the preparation of hybrid materials for more details). In addition, the new CYCU-3′ 50_50 structure has 1D channels that represent the small pores of CYCU-3. On the other hand, the disordered nature of the CYCU-3′ 50_50 crystals (Figure S4) could be caused by the coordination of acetate instead of the SDC ligands to the Al centers, not only in the crystal surface but also in the inner structure, creating defects (a). This hypothesis is further supported by the elemental analysis, in which a high acetate/SDC ratio of 1.63 was found. To confirm the structural model, ED pattern simulation was applied (b). The experimental ED pattern of CYCU-3′ 50_50 (b-I) was compared with the CYCU-3′ 50_50 average model (b-III) and the simulated ED pattern of CYCU-3 (b-II, generated from the previously reported CYCU-3 structure). Extra diffraction rows are observed in b-I, which agrees well with the pattern from the CYCU-3′ 50_50 average model (b-II), whereas the simulated ED pattern of CYCU-3 lacks these rows (b-III). This suggests that the proposed model of CYCU-3′ 50_50 is correct, and it is of a different phase from the original CYCU-3. However, the high degree of disorder found in CYCU-3′ 50_50 may be caused by the previously mentioned ligand defects and/or by the missing AlO6 chains.

Afterward, the matrixes were activated (150 °C under vacuum for 24 h), and the TGA measurements of the desolvated materials were recorded, confirming that, in all cases, the CYCU-3 materials were free of ligands and/or solvent molecules, as no mass loss was observed up to ∼350 °C (Figure S7). Regarding thermal stability, the decomposition temperature increases with particle size (ca. 351, 408, and 473 °C for CYCU-3 20_0, CYCU-3 50_5, and CYCU-3′ 50_50, respectively). In addition, we evaluated the permanent porosity of these materials by measuring the nitrogen adsorption isotherms at 77 K (Figure S8). In all cases, the isotherm profiles were characteristic of the materials with both micro- and mesopores. Besides, CYCU-3 20_0 and CYCU-3 50_5 exhibited a similar BET surface areas (2225 and 2270 m2 g–1, respectively) than that previously reported for pristine CYCU-3 (2760 m2 g–1), whereas the adsorption capacity of CYCU-3′ 50_50 was markedly lower (265 m2 g–1), probably because of its more dense framework compared to that of pristine CYCU-3 (see the structural studies for more details). The pore size distribution of the different porous frameworks was also determined (Figure S9).

Evaluation of ALF794@CYCU-3 Hybrid Materials as Potential CORMAs

To test the potential biological application as CORMAs of ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50, their photoinduced CO release properties were first investigated in solution (10 mM PBS, 37 °C) by UV–vis spectroscopy using the myoglobin assay. Although both the hybrid materials released appreciable amounts of CO (0.46 and 0.24 mmol of CO per mmol of CORM, respectively, upon 24 h of irradiation with visible light, Figure S12), molybdenum leaching was also detected (94 and 25%, respectively, after 6 h of incubation with no further leaching in the next 72 h) (Table S1). The high extent of metal leaching from ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 might be attributed to its smaller particle size, which unfortunately leads to a high degradation of the framework in PBS. In contrast, ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50 shows a significantly lower metal leaching (25% of Mo) related to its less porous structure and larger particle size. Taking into account the latter fact, ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50 is the only hybrid material that can be considered as a real CORMA in solution.

To further explore the ability of these hybrid systems as CORMAs, we decided to study their CO delivery properties in the solid state, envisaging their potential use for topical applications (i.e., anti-inflammatory bandages). In this context, the previously reported innovative application of photoactive CORMs for topical treatment of epidermal cancer should be highlighted. Indeed, CORM-2, [Ru2Cl4(CO)6], lotions were shown to reduce the acute and chronic inflammation and tumor multiplicity in hairless mice with induced photocarcinogenesis. Thus, an in-line CO detector was customized to measure the CO released from the ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50 solid matrixes (Figure S13). In particular, both hybrid materials were spin-coated and irradiated at 250–385 nm with 50 mW cm–2 of light power to promote the CO release. The delivered CO was transferred using N2 as the carrier gas to the in-line detector. The CO release efficiencies of the ALF794-loaded materials were compared to that of free CORM (). Thus, pristine ALF794 behaves also as a photoCORM in the solid state, releasing 0.42 mmol of CO per mmol of CORM after 220 min (photo-releasing efficiency: 42%). In addition, both hybrid materials retain the photoactive properties of the molybdenum tricarbonyl complex, showing an average CO delivery of 0.44 and 0.35 mmol of CO per mmol of CORM (44 and 35% of CO release efficiency) for ALF794@CYCU-3 50_5 and ALF794@CYCU-3′ 50_50, respectively.

Structural Studies of the New Phase CYCU-3'

As mentioned before, to further clarify the nature of the isolated CYCU-3' x_50 materials, we modeled the CYCU-3' 50_50 structure by CRED. For this purpose, the images of the CYCU-3' 50_50 material were obtained using a transmission electron microscope, and the ED data of a selected area were recorded. The crystals have long ribbon-like morphology (Figure S3), as previously observed in the corresponding SEM images (Figure S2). The 3D reciprocal lattice of CYCU-3' 50_50 was reconstructed from the ED frames (Figure S4) and used for the determination of the unit cell parameters (a = 16.35 Å, b = 62.15 Å, c = 6.73 Å, α = 89.7°, β = 94.5°, and γ = 88.1°). These values showed some differences, particularly in the a-axis and β angle, in comparison to those of pristine CYCU-3 (a = 34.067 Å, b = 60.07 Å, c = 6.312 Å, α = 90.0°, β = 90.0°, and γ = 90.0°), which may suggest that CYCU-3' 50_50 is a new structure of the original MOF. Unfortunately, the CYCU-3' 50_50 structure is disordered along the b axis, as severe diffraction streaks along this direction were observed in the reconstructed 3D reciprocal lattice (Figure S4).
